title: PM Update: Heat and humidity return Saturday, then it’s slightly less toasty Sunday
text:
A shooting star and the Milky Way from Calvert County. (Beau Finley/Flickr)

It was another cooler than recent times kind of day that wasn’t all that cool. Highs near and above 80 are about five to seven degrees above normal for the date. Lower humidity and a breeze helped negate that a good deal, but perhaps also a little frustrating to miss out on those mid-70s average highs! Today’s as low as we’ll see high temperatures rise for a while.

Listen to our daily D.C. forecasts: Apple Podcasts | Amazon Echo | More options

Through Tonight: Our break in the humidity ends up short lived as winds from the south are already pumping more moisture into the area. This helps keep lows up from last night, with most spots settling to the 60s. Under partly cloudy skies, winds continue to blow around 5 mph after dark, from the south.

View the current weather at The Washington Post.

Tomorrow (Saturday): Skies are mostly sunny early, and high levels of humidity -- dew points approaching 70 -- make it feel a bit icky. Highs should rise to the mid-80s in the cooler spots north and west to as high as the low 90s in the hottest locations. We’ll need to eye the potential of some afternoon or evening storms moving in from the west. Whether they survive the journey is still to be decided.

Sunday: We’re behind a weak front by Sunday, which means it should be a touch cooler than Saturday, but perhaps not much. Highs are largely in the mid-and-upper 80s. Sunshine rules once again, and humidity is still rather high, so it’ll still be feeling like summer.

See Camden Walker’s forecast through the beginning of next week. And if you haven’t already, join us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter and Instagram. For related traffic news, check out Gridlock.

Pollen update: Tree pollen, weed pollen, and mold spores are low/moderate.

Want our 5 a.m. forecast delivered to your email in-box? Subscribe here.
description: This weekend feels more like summer than fall.
authors: Ian Livingston Is A Forecaster Photographer
Information Lead For The Capital Weather Gang. Day
National Security Researcher At A D.C. Think Tank.
